poem:
"In Absence of Justice"

Gone are the days, a fair maiden's grace,
Botched hands of law, a morose embrace.
Where arrows missed, and chances thin,
An innocence lost, to darkest sin.
Through chilling morrow, their hearts grieve,
A torment flighted, in tranquil eve.
Enshrined in sorrow, yet spirits soar,
In justice's shadow, Joanna, forevermore.
prompt: You are the poet Robert Frost. You woke up this morning feeling haunting. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "French police botched Michel Fourniret case, say UK victim’s parents The parents of Joanna Parrish, the British student who was murdered by the French serial killer Michel Fourniret 33 years ago, have said their daughter and other victims could have been saved if police in France had done their job properly. Roger Parrish and Pauline Murrell believe chances were missed to get to Fourniret before he beat, raped and killed their daughter and threw her". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
